title: 107_hr1054
content: The "Truth in Lending Modernization Act of 2001" amends the Consumer Credit Protection Act to increase the threshold for credit and lease transactions from $25,000 to $75,000. It also includes amendments related to the right of rescission. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to establish the right of a consumer to rescind a transaction. A consumer's election to waive this right is not effective if it was required by the creditor, advised or encouraged by the creditor, or discussed by the creditor during the transaction. The Truth in Lending Act allows consumers to rescind a transaction, and any waiver of this right is not valid if influenced by the creditor. Amendments also address noncompliance with requirements in foreclosure proceedings. The Truth in Lending Act allows consumers to rescind transactions and prohibits waivers influenced by creditors. Amendments also address noncompliance in foreclosure proceedings, including civil liability. Amendments to the Consumer Credit Protection Act increase the maximum liability amounts for noncompliance. The maximum amount of liability is now determined by multiplying the maximum amount under subparagraph (A) by the number of members in the certified class. The maximum liability amount for noncompliance under the Consumer Credit Protection Act is now determined by multiplying the maximum amount by the number of members in the certified class or 2 percent of the creditor's net worth. SEC. 5 prohibits the use of Rule of 78s and amends the Housing and Community Development Act of 1992. SEC. 6 provides access to court provision. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to ensure that consumers have the right to bring legal action against creditors, prohibiting binding arbitration or nonjudicial procedures that would deny this right. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to allow consumers to take legal action against creditors, ensuring they are not denied the right to bring a lawsuit under this title. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to allow consumers to take legal action against creditors within a 6-month period for implementing the amendments made by this Act.
